repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - National Water Rehabilitation,
            First Multi-State Water Supply, and Small Towns Water Supply
            and Sanitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Rehabilitation, the
            First Multi-State, and the Small Towns Water Supply projects
            were selected for this cluster assessment in order to
            evaluate the reasons for the failure of the Bank's
            assistance to the Nigerian water supply sector in the
            1979-2004 period.  These projects represent a clear
            evolution in the scope of World Bank lending: the first
            project was nationwide and concentrated on procurement and
            installation of equipment in selected water systems in each
            of the 36 Nigerian states and the National Federal
            Territory; the second project was restricted to two states
            (Kaduna and Katsina); and the third project directly
            assisted 16 small towns. This assessment rated the outcome
            of the National Water Rehabilitation Project as highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, negligible
            institutional development Impact, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower.  For the First
            Multi-State Water Supply Project, the assessment concurred
            with the completion report, except that the PPAR rated the
            outcome as moderately satisfactory. The PPAR rated the
            outcome of the Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project as satisfactory with likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            There are three principal lessons: First, the targets under
            the MDGs for water supply and sanitation, focusing only on
            service coverage and access, need to be expanded to include
            the reliability and quality of water supplies.  Second,
            effective coordination between central, state and local
            governments requires demand-driven approaches where the
            consumers have the initiative. Third, maintenance merits
            priority over new works.

6933883.trustfund:
TF027200-NATIONAL WATER REHABILITATION FUND,TF040474-NIGERIA:  STATE WATER I -
            PROJECT ANALYSIS IN PREPARATION OF THE ICR,TF038558-NIGERIA: SMALL TOWNS W. SUPPLY
            & SANITATION PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts only modest. Lessons are outlined as
            follows. While the project was limited in its scope to
            rehabilitation, and institutional building within the State
            Water Agency (SWA), thus limited in its impact, the Bank
            rightly used the project to initiate, and promote policy
            reforms. To this end, the sector was well positioned on the
            national agenda - once political stabilization was achieved
            - and, it is important to note that this could not have been
            achieved, had it not been for the interest emerged,
            championed within the country, for initiating, and
            implementing reforms. However, it also holds true that in a
            country where logistics are often difficult, projects should
            be kept focused only on few states: management
            infrastructure was weak to supervise the large number of
            subprojects, which led to delays; rather a focus on full
            rehabilitation would have been preferred, which could have
            raised awareness, and capacity building within all SWAs.
            This obviously led to a large number of small contracts,
            which could not attract international contractors, but
            instead overstreched national capacity. In designing water
            supply works, perspectives should lie on getting water to
            the ultimate beneficiary: benefits however were constrained
            by inadequate distribution networks, a factor which could
            have been solved by the SWAs financing additional works
            themselves, provided political stability existed. Other
            lessons reinforce project preparation be well advanced prior
            to loan effectiveness; funds should be secured; Project
            Preparation Facility mechanisms be used as needed; and,
            reliable performance indicators facilitate the monitoring process.

5077567.owner: AFT:  Urban/Water Francophone (AFTU2),Env., NRM, WRM & DRM Prac 2 (AFTN2),8841
5077567.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will provide a source of
            credit to finance state level sub-projects to address the
            highest priority rehabilitation needs of urban water supply
            systems.  Sub-projects will focus on rehabilitating existing
            facilities, leakage detection and repair and institutional
            strengthening to improve operation and maintenance as well
            as financial, personnel and stores management of the
            participating State Water Agencies (SWAs).  The project will
            also support measures to strengthen the Federal Ministry of
            Water Resources (FMWR) to fulfill its role as an advisory
            and coordinating agency for the water supply sector.
